title: For Ken Burns, ‘Country Music’ Is the Song of America
text:
Ken Burns has made about 30 films over his long career. But his latest documentary, “Country Music,” which premieres Sept. 15 on PBS, presented a new set of challenges.

Its very subject matter was a turnoff to some people, perceived at times as a “country cousin,” Mr. Burns says, a musical “bottomland not befitting the attention of sophisticates and, God forbid, scholars.” The filmmakers wanted to convey a level of nuance, more complex than trains and whiskey, heartbreak and going home to Mama. The music’s story mirrored America’s, expressed by performers who often echoed their tragic personal narratives in songs.

The 16-hour, eight-part series features all the Burns hallmarks: evocative music, leisurely interviews and archival images made famous in works like “Baseball” (1994) and “The Civil War” (1990). Beneath the historical turmoil depicted on screen, there is a nostalgic faith in America. Many Burns films feature academics. Here, the only scholar is Bill Malone, author of “Country Music USA,” first published in 1968. Talking heads include Dolly Parton, Vince Gill, Loretta Lynn, Wynton Marsalis, Elvis Costello and Rosanne Cash.

Country music had so many influences and reached so many places that the initial structuring of the film was an organizational feat. With Mr. Burns presiding over several films at once, that fell to writer-producer Dayton Duncan, who has worked with him for nearly 30 years, including on films about national parks, Mark Twain and Lewis and Clark. Growing up in Iowa, Mr. Duncan didn’t listen to country music, but in the 1970s he leapt into it, partly by discovering Emmylou Harris, a fixture in the series. In 2011 he and his team began reading hundreds of books and listening to records.

The next year, deep in research, Mr. Duncan drove to Portsmouth, N.H., to meet Merle Haggard, who had been ill but was back on the road. He presented the singer with a copy of their 2012 documentary, “The Dust Bowl,” and they talked for an hour on the tour bus. Haggard was a legend for his 50 years of music, his parents’ migration from Oklahoma to California, his time in San Quentin and his five marriages. Mr. Duncan wasn’t yet scheduling interviews but knew he needed this man on camera. He got him, before Haggard died four years later. Of the 101 people whose interviews were used in the film, 20 have died.

“I staged the interviews sort of based on actuarial tables,” Mr. Duncan said. “We went to the oldest ones first.”

Merle Haggard, with Dayton Duncan in December 2014, spoke with the filmmakers about his 50 years in music. Photo: Jared Ames

The documentary ranges from the 1920s to 1996, when Bill Monroe died and Garth Brooks broke sales records. The stopping point was critical: The filmmakers are historians, and history needs time to settle. “We could have a great conversation about whether Blake Shelton or Taylor Swift will endure as significant artists in 20 years,” Mr. Duncan says. “Maybe, maybe not.”

Haggard made sure the filmmakers were aware of Jimmie Rodgers and Bob Wills and the Texas Playboys. He mentioned the lesser-known Maddox Brothers and Rose, who were among the creators of California’s “Bakersfield Sound”—a rival to the Nashville music scene. Haggard also cited Emmett Miller, father of the classic “Lovesick Blues,” who performed in blackface at minstrel shows.

“Country Music” moves through the Depression and wars and business and the women’s movement as well as blues, gospel, jazz, R&B, soul and folk. Rock ’n’ roll terrified Nashville’s overlords even while the early Beatles sang Buck Owens’s “Act Naturally” and the likes of Gram Parsons and Bob Dylan further blended country and rock. Viewers also meet Marty Stuart, the unofficial curator of history and artifacts in Nashville. Mr. Stuart, a musician, is a link between Americana/roots music and mainstream commercial country—which often are at odds.

Dolly Parton with Dayton Duncan, center, and Ken Burns in November 2016, is among the performers interviewed for ‘Country Music.’ Photo: Katy Haas

Country singers and songwriters resisted barriers, opting simply to make American music. The filmmakers point out the many African-American influences: The banjo came from Africa. Hank Williams, Rodgers and A.P. Carter all had African-American mentors.

Among audiences, racial divides persisted for years. For decades, there were few black faces in the crowds at the Grand Ole Opry , a Nashville institution. When Charley Pride began crooning hits in the mid-1960s, many were shocked to learn that this son of a Mississippi sharecropper was black. His label wouldn’t release his version of “Green, Green Grass of Home” as a single because the song refers to “sweet Mary” with “hair of gold.”

In 1962, when Ray Charles first won creative control of one of his albums, he named it “Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music” and in 1962 sent “I Can’t Stop Lovin’ You” to No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100. In New York, jazz great Charlie Parker would play country on the jukebox between sets and tell skeptics: “Listen to the stories.”

Some of the musicians in “Country Music,” resurface in very different places. Willie Nelson wrote “Crazy” for Patsy Cline, but was frustrated in Nashville, where producers had him wear turtlenecks and sing lush arrangements. He and Waylon Jennings grew their hair and beards and Mr. Nelson headed home to Texas. They became stars of “outlaw” country and Mr. Nelson became even more famous by singing American-songbook standards like “Stardust.”

“Country Music” rests on two building blocks, which the filmmakers call Saturday Night and Sunday Morning. Members of the Carter Family, exemplars of the latter camp, were about church, home and Appalachian hills, with songs such as “Keep on the Sunny Side.” The rougher, Saturday Night strain was personified by the vagabond Jimmie Rodgers, whose songs such as “Mule Skinner Blues” chronicled riding the rails, drinking, gambling and landing in jail. The two camps are reflected in the tumultuous lives of Hank Williams, Patsy Cline, Bill Monroe, Loretta Lynn, George Jones, Tammy Wynette and others.

Johnny Cash looms large in the film as a giant tangle of both strains, tortured by pain and pills and at times seeking redemption through the gospel music of his Arkansas youth. Cash, who married a Carter Family daughter, June, in 1968, made a hit out of Kris Kristofferson’s lyrical hangover song “Sunday Morning Coming Down.”

“To us he’s the avatar,” Mr. Duncan says. “It’s a wide-arm embrace of all the different styles of music and the social and personal conflicts of the 20th century.”

For Mr. Cash, the filmmakers even bent their decision not to go beyond 1996. They included his death—in 2003—in the final episode of “Country Music.”
description: In a new PBS series, the director of “The Civil War,” “Baseball” and other documentaries, portrays America’s development through the lens of country music.
